Introduction
Idempotent ultralters are a central object in Ramsey theory of numbers. Over
the last forty years they have been extensively studied in the literature, producing
a great amount of interesting combinatorial properties (see the extensive monogra-
phy [12]). As reported in [11], it all started in 1971 when F. Galvin realized that by
assuming the existence of ultralters on N that are almost translation invariant,
one could produce a short proof of a conjecture of R. Graham and B. Rothschild,
that was to become a cornerstone of Ramsey theory of numbers: For every nite
coloring of the natural numbers there exists an innite set X such that all nite
sums of distinct elements of X have the same color. However, at that time the
problem was left open as whether such special ultralters could exist at all.
In
1972, N. Hindman [9] showed that the continuum hypothesis suces to construct
those ultralters, but their existence in ZFC remained unresolved. Eventually, in
1974, N. Hindman [10] proved Graham-Rothschild conjecture (now known as Hind-
mans Theorem) with a long and intricate combinatorial argument that avoided
the use of ultralters. Shortly afterwards, in 1975, S. Glazer observed that al-
most translation invariant ultralters are precisely the idempotent elements of the
semigroup (N, ), where N is the Stone- Cech compactication of the discrete
space N (which can be identied with the space of ultralters on N) and where
is a suitable pseudo-sum operation between ultralters. The existence of idempo-
tent ultralters is then immediate, since any compact Hausdor right-topological
semigroup has idempotents, a well-known fact in semigroup theory known as Ellis-
Numakuras Lemma. The proof of that lemma heavily relies on the axiom of choice,
as it consists in a clever and elegant use of Zorns Lemma jointly with the topolog-
ical properties of a compact Hausdor space. In 1989, T. Papazyan [16] introduced
the notion of almost translation invariant lter , and proved that the maximal l-
ters in that class, obtained by applying Zorns Lemma, are necessarily ultralters,
and hence idempotent ultralters.

Despite their central role in a whole area of combinatorics of numbers, no other
proofs are known for the existence of idempotent ultralters. However, as it of-
ten happens with fundamental objects of mathematics, alternative proofs seem
desirable because they may give a better insight and potentially lead to new appli-
cations. It is worth mentioning that generalizations of idempotent ultralters have
been recently considered both in the usual set-theoretic context, and in the general
framework of model theory: see [15] where P. Krautzberger thoroughly investigated
the almost translation invariant lters (appropriately named idempotent lters),
and see [1] where U. Andrews and I. Goldbring studied a model-theoretic notion of
idempotent type and its relationship with Hindmans Theorem.
In this paper we introduce the notion of additive lter, which is weaker than
the notion of idempotent lter. By suitably modifying the argument used in Ellis-
Numakuras Lemma, we show that Zorns Lemma is not needed to prove that every
additive lter can be extended to a maximal additive lter, and that every maximal
additive lter is indeed an idempotent ultralter. Precisely, we will only assume
the following restricted form of the Ultralter Theorem (a strictly weaker form of
the axiom of choice): Every lter on R can be extended to an ultralter.
